**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Closed captions; Spanish subtitles; ASL interpreter on-screen; free registration with suggested donation; accessible to homebound supporters.

**Differentiation Hook:** Virtual = zero weather risk, broadest geographic reach; storytelling depth impossible at large in-person events; ultra-low overhead.

**Revenue Model:** Suggested $25–40 household donation; peer-to-peer fundraising (hosts virtual watch parties); sponsor "chapters" of the broadcast ($1,000 each); text-to-give during program.

**Cost Drivers:** AV production (local videographer or volunteer); watch-party kit mailing; platform fees (YouTube/Facebook free option).

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—single evening, minimal setup, reusable content; development coordinator can manage with videographer.

---

### 6. BREAKFAST ON THE FARM SERIES
**Tagline/Theme:** Four Saturdays, four farms, fresh starts for fresh food access.

**Mission Connection:** Each breakfast happens at a farm that partners with our pantry supply chain; farmers explain how mobile distribution expands their reach to neighbors in need.

**Audience Fit:** Families love farm visits; small business owners appreciate early networking; scalable model tests interest before committing to large event.

**Experience:** 8–10am Saturday breakfast (pancakes, eggs, sausage from farm); farm tour; kids meet animals; storytelling from farmer + pantry client; coffee and conversation.

**Venue/Season:** Four Saturdays in May; rotating farms; outdoor with barn backup.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Choose farms with accessible paths (gravel, paved); hay-bale seating plus chairs; Spanish interpretation at one site with higher Latinx population; $25–30 sliding scale family rate.

**Differentiation Hook:** Series format spreads risk and workload; farm settings differentiate from all competing events; repeatable = relationship-building.

**Revenue Model:** Ticket $30 adults, $15 kids (or $75 family); farm sponsorships ($1,000 per breakfast); recipe booklet sales; "Adopt a Route" campaign launched at series.

**Cost Drivers:** Food (partially donated by farms); porta-potties; printing; small stipends to host farms.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW PER EVENT (30–40 guests each; 120–160 total); scalable pilot; farms provide venue and volunteers help setup.

---

### 7. APPALACHIAN FOOD JUSTICE FILM NIGHT
**Tagline/Theme:** Watch, learn, act—cinema that feeds change.

**Mission Connection:** Screen a food justice documentary (e.g., "A Place at the Table," regional short films) followed by panel discussion featuring clients, farmers, healthcare partners addressing local food access realities.

**Audience Fit:** Teachers and mission-driven families value educational events; lower ticket price accessible; evening timing works for working supporters.

**Experience:** Film screening (60–75 min); moderated panel (20 min); mobile pantry truck displayed outside; reception with local snacks; action cards (volunteer, donate, advocate).

**Venue/Season:** Indoor (school auditorium, church, community theater) late April; weather-proof; evening 6:30pm.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Wheelchair-accessible venue with accessible restrooms; closed captions; Spanish subtitles (choose bilingual film); low-sensory option (dimmed house lights); $15–25 sliding scale.

**Differentiation Hook:** Educational angle distinct from social events; film draws curiosity; panel localizes national issues; low-cost high-impact format.

**Revenue Model:** Ticket $20–25; concessions benefit organization; program ad sales ($100–300); sponsor the screening ($2,000 presenting); text-to-give appeal post-panel.

**Cost Drivers:** Film licensing ($150–500); venue rental (seek in-kind); panelist honoraria (in-kind); AV tech.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—single evening, straightforward logistics, school/theater handles AV; panel recruited from existing partners.

---

### 8. COOKBOOK LAUNCH & TASTING PARTY
**Tagline/Theme:** Recipes from the hollers—flavor, heritage, and food security in every dish.

**Mission Connection:** Publish a community cookbook featuring recipes from clients, farmers, and volunteers; proceeds fund mobile pantry; launch party showcases the dishes and storytellers.

**Audience Fit:** Church groups and families love cookbooks and food traditions; tangible product has lasting value; supports local storytelling.

**Experience:** Tasting stations featuring 10–12 cookbook recipes; storytellers share dish origins; live music; cookbook signing; pre-orders and sales; cooking demo by client or farmer.

**Venue/Season:** Indoor (community center, church hall) early May; accessible kitchen for demos.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Wheelchair-accessible venue and tasting stations; recipe cards in Spanish; allergen labeling; $25–30 ticket includes cookbook; low-sensory seating area.

**Differentiation Hook:** Cookbook is a revenue generator beyond the event (ongoing sales); celebrates Appalachian food heritage; avoids cook-off competition format.

**Revenue Model:** Ticket $30 (includes cookbook valued $15); cookbook pre-sales and bulk orders; recipe sponsorships in book ($250–500); direct appeal during program.

**Cost Drivers:** Cookbook printing (offset by sales and sponsorships); food for tastings (donated/cost-shared); venue.

**Capacity Intensity:** MEDIUM—cookbook production is upfront work (can outsource to volunteer committee months ahead); event itself straightforward with volunteer cooks.

---

### 9. LIGHTNING CHALLENGE: 24 HOURS FOR 24 ROUTES
**Tagline/Theme:** One day, one goal—fund a full year of mobile pantry routes.

**Mission Connection:** Peer-to-peer giving day where supporters recruit friends/family to donate; track progress toward funding all 24 monthly routes; mobile pantry makes surprise visits to donors.

**Audience Fit:** Small business owners and teachers comfortable with social media; competitive/gamified format energizes younger supporters; low time commitment.

**Experience:** Virtual + optional in-person kickoff breakfast; 24-hour Facebook/email fundraising blitz; leaderboard updates; matching gift incentives; celebration video at hour 24.

**Venue/Season:** Mid-May (avoids April crowding); virtual with optional 7am kickoff breakfast (Extension building, 30–50 champions).

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Fully accessible virtual platform; Spanish toolkit for peer fundraisers; no ticket required—participation-based; digital accessibility (screen reader compatible).

**Differentiation Hook:** Ultra-low overhead; broad reach beyond Pike County; urgency drives participation; avoids event fatigue.

**Revenue Model:** Peer-to-peer fundraising (100+ fundraisers @ $200+ each); matching gifts ($5,000 secured in advance); leadership gifts ($1,000+) announced as "route sponsors."

**Cost Drivers:** Giving day platform ($300–500 or free Facebook); kickoff breakfast; promotional printing/digital ads.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—mostly digital; development coordinator manages platform; volunteer ambassadors recruit peer fundraisers; reusable model.

---

### 10. PORCH PARTY HOUSE CONCERTS SERIES
**Tagline/Theme:** Music in the hollers—intimate concerts funding food access.

**Mission Connection:** Supporters host 8–12 person house concerts on their porches/homes; traveling musicians (bluegrass, gospel) donate time; intimate setting fosters deep mission connection and storytelling.

**Audience Fit:** Church groups and small business owners host in their homes; guests are invited friends (natural peer network expansion); low-pressure social atmosphere.

**Experience:** Host provides venue + light refreshments; musician performs 45-min set; ED or client shares 10-min story; guests make donations/pledges; 6–8 concerts over three weekends.

**Venue/Season:** Late April–early May; private homes/porches across Pike County; weather-flexible (move inside).

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Hosts commit to accessible entry; interpretation provided where needed; sliding-scale suggested donation; low-sensory small group naturally accommodating.

**Differentiation Hook:** Hyper-local, relationship-driven; avoids large-venue logistics and costs; scalable and repeatable; music without barn dance overhead.

**Revenue Model:** Suggested $50–100 donation per guest (6–8 guests × 6–8 concerts = 36–64 donors); hosts pledge to raise $500–800 per concert; musician tip jar benefits pantry.

**Cost Drivers:** Musician stipends (seek donated performances); printed programs; host training/supplies.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW PER EVENT; hosts shoulder logistics; development coordinator trains hosts and provides kits; volunteer coordinator manages schedule.

---

### 11. Route RIDE-ALONG EXPERIENCE AUCTION
**Tagline/Theme:** Ride the route, see the need—exclusive mobile pantry experiences up for bid.

**Mission Connection:** Winners ride along on actual mobile pantry routes, meet clients, see hollers without grocery access firsthand; transforms abstract mission into visceral understanding.

**Experience:** Online/silent auction (2 weeks) leading to small celebration reception; 8–12 ride-along slots (different routes/dates); winners receive tour, lunch with driver, impact report.

**Venue/Season:** Virtual auction April 15–29; ride-alongs occur May–June; reception at Extension building early May.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Virtual auction accessible; ride-alongs accommodate mobility needs (truck is accessible); Spanish interpretation for bilingual routes; scholarship slots for non-bidders (lottery).

**Differentiation Hook:** Experiential philanthropy; educates major donor prospects deeply; auction format familiar but item is unique; virtually no overhead.

**Revenue Model:** Ride-along bids ($250–500 suggested); additional auction items (farm dinners, crafts); "Fund a Route" direct giving option; reception ticket sales ($25).

**Cost Drivers:** Auction platform (free option: Facebook/email); reception food; printing.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—auction is virtual; ride-alongs happen during regular routes (no extra event); reception simple.

---

### 12. GROWING HOPE COMMUNITY BREAKFAST (Hybrid)
**Tagline/Theme:** Break bread, break barriers—together at the table and online.

**Mission Connection:** Traditional pancake breakfast with livestreamed program portion (stories, mobile pantry video); in-person guests see the truck; virtual guests nationwide can participate.

**Audience Fit:** Church groups and families attend in-person; distant supporters/alumni join virtually; all-ages friendly; morning timing works for families.

**Experience:** In-person: pancake breakfast, mobile pantry tours, kids' activities, storytelling program (livestreamed). Virtual: watch program, participate in chat, receive mailed recipe cards and seeds.

**Venue/Season:** Early May, 9am–12pm; church fellowship hall or community center with AV; outdoor truck display.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Wheelchair-accessible venue; ASL and Spanish interpretation on livestream; closed captions; $10–15 in-person (kids under 12 free); virtual suggested $25 household donation; low-sensory room available.

**Differentiation Hook:** Hybrid reaches beyond Pike County; breakfast format familiar/comfortable but enhanced with digital reach; avoids competing with fish fries (different protein, different time).

**Revenue Model:** In-person ticket $12–15; virtual household donation $25–40; sponsorships ($1,000–2,000); text-to-give during program; cookbook sales.

**Cost Drivers:** Food (pancakes, sausage—partially donated); livestream production; printing.

**Capacity Intensity:** MEDIUM—dual format adds complexity but leverages existing breakfast model; church volunteers handle food; development coordinator manages virtual.

---

### 13. SPONSOR-A-MILE ROUTE MAPPING CAMPAIGN
**Tagline/Theme:** Every mile matters—fund the routes that feed our neighbors.

**Mission Connection:** Create visual map showing all mobile pantry routes; donors "sponsor" individual miles ($50–100 each); map displayed at culminating open house event where clients and donors meet.

**Audience Fit:** Small business owners like named sponsorship; visual map creates tangible connection; teachers can involve classes in mapping project; community-building culmination.

**Experience:** 3-week campaign (mostly virtual/mail) followed by May open house celebration; map unveiling; mobile pantry demos; refreshments; client storytelling.

**Venue/Season:** Campaign late April; open house early May at Extension building or church.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Virtual participation option; open house wheelchair-accessible; Spanish map and materials; sliding-scale mile sponsorships ($25–100); kids can sponsor with class fundraiser.

**Differentiation Hook:** Visual, geographic storytelling; campaign plus event hybrid; sponsorship at accessible price points; map becomes permanent display/stewardship tool.

**Revenue Model:** Mile sponsorships $50–100 (200+ miles available); business route sponsorships ($500–1,000); open house ticket donations ($15–20); matching gift from lead sponsor.

**Cost Drivers:** Map design/printing (can be in-kind from designer); open house food; promotional mailings.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—campaign is mail/digital; open house simple reception; map design outsourced to volunteer; volunteer coordinator manages route data.

---

### 14. SPRING MARKET VENDOR FESTIVAL
**Tagline/Theme:** Shop local, feed neighbors—every purchase plants hope.

**Mission Connection:** Partner with Pikeville Farmers Market for special festival day; 10% of all vendor sales donated to mobile pantry; showcases the farmers we buy from and distribute.

**Audience Fit:** Families love market atmosphere; small business owners network with vendors; supports local economy while funding mission; shopping is the participation.

**Experience:** Expanded Saturday market (20–30 vendors); live music; kids' activities; mobile pantry truck on-site; cooking demos; "Pantry Passport" game (visit vendors, win prize).

**Venue/Season:** Early May Saturday; Farmers Market location or church parking lot; outdoor with tent backup.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Wheelchair-accessible layout; Spanish interpretation at info booth; sliding-scale pantry passport ($5–10 donation); sensory-friendly hours (8–10am quiet).

**Differentiation Hook:** Leverages existing market infrastructure; vendors share promotion; supports local food economy holistically; vendor donation model reduces direct fundraising lift.

**Revenue Model:** Vendor sales donations (10% = estimated $1,500–2,500); passport game ($10 suggested); sponsorships ($500–1,500); direct donation booth; cookbook sales.

**Cost Drivers:** Tents/tables (partner with market); entertainment; printing; kids' activity supplies.

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—Farmers Market handles vendor logistics; volunteers manage pantry activities; piggybacks on existing event.

---

### 15. GRATITUDE GATHERING DONOR APPRECIATION (Scalable Pilot)
**Tagline/Theme:** Thank you from the hollers—a celebration of community impact.

**Mission Connection:** Invite 2024 donors for intimate appreciation event; share impact stories, give mobile pantry tours, soft-launch 2025 giving opportunities; tests stewardship-to-solicitation model.

**Audience Fit:** Existing donors (small business owners, church groups, teachers) feel valued; low-pressure renewal atmosphere; relationship-building for future asks.

**Experience:** Evening dessert reception (6–8pm); video impact report premiere; client storytelling; mobile pantry tours; "2025 Route Preview" presentation; pledge cards available (no hard ask).

**Venue/Season:** Late April; church fellowship hall or community center; indoor.

**Accessibility/Inclusion:** Wheelchair-accessible venue; Spanish interpretation; desserts accommodate dietary needs; no ticket (invitational); low-sensory design.

**Differentiation Hook:** Stewardship-first approach builds loyalty; soft-pilots storytelling and program content for larger events; small scale = high-touch.

**Revenue Model:** No ticket; voluntary pledge cards for 2025 giving; "Invite a Friend" expansion option (friends pay $25); tests donor upgrade model (50–75 attendees).

**Cost Drivers:** Desserts (donated from bakeries/volunteers); printing; video production (reusable content).

**Capacity Intensity:** LOW—small guest list, simple format, high volunteer engagement from grateful past participants; tests concept for scaling.

---

## 3) COMPARISON MATRIX

| Concept # & Title | Mission Alignment | Net Revenue Potential | Audience Appeal | Differentiation | Feasibility/Capacity | TOTAL SCORE |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1. Taste of the Hollers Progressive Dinner | 5 | 4 | 4 | 5 | 3 | 21 |
| 2. Seeds & Stories Garden Party | 5 | 4 | 5 | 4 | 4 | 22 |
| 3. Empty Bowl Supper | 5 | 3 | 5 | 4 | 5 | 22 |
| 4. Mobile Market Celebration & Auction | 5 | 5 | 4 | 5 | 3 | 22 |
| 5. Virtual Holler Hall Storytelling Night | 5 | 3 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 20 |
| 6. Breakfast on the Farm Series | 4 | 4 | 5 | 4 | 5 | 22 |
| 7. Appalachian Food Justice Film Night | 4 | 3 | 4 | 4 | 5 | 20 |
| 8. Cookbook Launch & Tasting Party | 4 | 4 | 5 | 3 | 3 | 19 |
| 9. Lightning Challenge: 24 Hours for 24 Routes | 4 | 5 | 3 | 5 | 5 | 22 |
| 10. Porch Party House Concerts Series | 5 | 4 | 4 | 5 | 5 | 23 |
| 11. Route Ride-Along Experience Auction | 5 | 3 | 3 | 5 | 5 | 21 |
| 12. Growing Hope Community Breakfast (Hybrid) | 5 | 4 | 5 | 3 | 3 | 20 |
| 13. Sponsor-A-Mile Route Mapping Campaign | 5 | 4 | 4 | 4 | 4 | 21 |
| 14. Spring Market Vendor Festival | 4 | 3 | 5 | 3 | 5 | 20 |
| 15. Gratitude Gathering Donor Appreciation | 4 | 2 | 4 | 3 | 5 | 18 |

**Scoring Key:**  
5 = Excellent; 4 = Good; 3 = Adequate; 2 = Weak; 1 = Poor

---

## 4) TOP 3 RECOMMENDATIONS

### **#1: PORCH PARTY HOUSE CONCERTS SERIES** (Score: 23)

**Why This Concept:** The distributed model spreads risk, minimizes single-event pressure, and leverages your strongest asset—community relationships. Hosts become fundraisers, reducing staff burden. Total net revenue potential of $12K–18K from 6–8 concerts fits your $20K goal when combined with sponsorships. Ultra-low overhead (under $800 total) preserves budget for mobile pantry expansion. The intimate setting naturally facilitates storytelling and highlights the mobile pantry mission authentically. Bluegrass music honors regional culture without replicating the barn dance's high volunteer lift.

**Key Risks:** Host recruitment may lag; inconsistent guest turnout per concert; musician availability in rural area.

**Mitigations:** Recruit 2–3 "champion hosts" early (board members, business owners) who model commitment. Provide host toolkit (invitation templates, suggested guest lists, talking points). Set minimum guest commitments (6 per concert). Partner with local musicians early; offer small stipends ($100–150) or in-kind appreciation. Schedule concerts on consecutive Fridays/Saturdays to maintain momentum.

**Quick Win Potential:** Pilot with ONE concert in late March at board member's home; test logistics, refine toolkit, gauge revenue ($500–800 proof-of-concept). If successful, scale to 6–8 concerts April–May. Minimal upfront investment; immediate feedback loop.

---

### **#2: SEEDS & STORIES GARDEN PARTY** (Score: 22)

**Why This Concept:** Aligns perfectly with May timing (post-frost, pre-county fair), outdoor setting, and educational mission. The Extension Service partnership provides venue, credibility, and volunteer support, reducing staff load. Garden theme resonates deeply with your rural audience's values and skills, differentiating from cook-offs and fish fries. Sponsorship of seed packets creates tangible donor connection. Revenue potential of $18K–22K net achievable through 150 attendees × $32 average + $7,500 sponsorships + auction. Weather backup (tent) addresses risk tolerance.

**Key Risks:** Weather dependency; outdoor accessibility challenges; volunteer coordination for multiple activity stations.

**Mitigations:** Secure large tent rental early (negotiate in-kind from sponsor); choose Extension demo garden with paved paths and accessible parking; recruit 15–20 volunteers from church groups and assign clear station roles 4 weeks out. Schedule rain date or move entirely under tent if forecast poor. Leverage Extension staff for garden content/demos.

**Quick Win Potential:** Partner with Extension to host a mini "Seed Swap Saturday" in March (30–40 people, free, story + seeds). Test storytelling format, gauge interest, build email list. Use feedback to refine May event. Cost under $200.

---

### **#3: MOBILE MARKET CELEBRATION & AUCTION** (Score: 22)

**Why This Concept:** The mobile pantry truck as centerpiece directly connects donors to mission impact—visual, tangible, memorable. Auction format is familiar to your small business owner demographic and generates strong net revenue ($15K–20K achievable). Outdoor market vibe feels celebratory, not obligatory. Sponsorable assets (truck tours, auction categories, food vendors) easily reach $7,500 target. April/May timing works; outdoor venue with tent backup manages weather risk.

**Key Risks:** Auction logistics (item procurement, bidding management); weather; volunteer capacity for setup/breakdown.

**Mitigations:** Recruit volunteer auction committee (3–4 people) in January to solicit 50+ items from farmers, businesses, artisans. Use simple paper bidding (no costly software) or free Google Forms for pre-bidding. Secure tent and tables early. Tap church volunteers for day-of setup (4-hour shifts). Create detailed run-of-show and assign roles.

**Quick Win Potential:** Test auction appeal with small "Basket Raffle" at February board meeting or church gathering—10 baskets, $5 tickets, track what sells. Validates donor appetite. Partner with Farmers Market to co-promote and source auction items early.

---

## 5) IMPLEMENTATION SUPPORT

### **Potential Partners/Hosts**

**Venues:**
- University of Kentucky Cooperative Extension Service (Pike County office and demo garden—accessible, mission-aligned, AV capable)
- First Baptist Church Pikeville, Shiloh United Methodist, St. Francis de Sales Catholic Church (fellowship halls, accessible parking, volunteer base)
- Pikeville City Park pavilion (outdoor, accessible, central)
- Local farms with accessible barn/outdoor spaces (for Breakfast on Farm or Garden Party)
- Pike County Public Library meeting room (Film Night, smaller gatherings)

**Community Partners:**
- **Cooperative Extension Service**: Co-host garden/farm events; provide educator volunteers, demo space, agricultural expertise
- **Pikeville Farmers Market**: Co-promote Spring Market Festival, source auction items, connect farmer storytellers
- **Appalachian Regional Healthcare**: Sponsor health/nutrition angle; provide Spanish interpretation resources; promote to staff
- **Local churches** (First Baptist, Shiloh UMC, St. Francis): Volunteer recruitment, host sites, fish fry collaboration (different weekends), potluck support
- **Pike County Schools** nutrition staff: Recipe contributions for cookbook; volunteer teachers
- **Local pottery studios/art programs**: Empty Bowl creation workshops
- **WMMT-FM (community radio)**: Media partnership for promotion and livestream support

**In-Kind Sources:**
- Tent/table rentals: Local funeral homes, party rental companies
- Printing: Regional print shops, UK Extension
- Food: Partner farms, church kitchens, local bakeries
- AV/tech: High school or community college media students, church tech volunteers

---

### **Talent/MC Ideas**

1. **Pastor or faith leader from partner church**: Trusted community voice; comfortable public speaking; can open with grace/welcome at any event; represents core audience demographic.

2. **Local farmer or Extension agent**: Agricultural credibility; can MC garden/farm events authentically; explains food systems accessibly; represents mission partnership.

3. **Retired teacher or principal**: Respected in community; strong ties to families and educators; comfortable facilitating panels or storytelling; approachable tone.

4. **Mobile pantry client volunteer**: Powerful authenticity; first-person perspective; engages audience emotionally; represents mission beneficiaries (provide coaching/support).

5. **Small business owner/board member**: Peer credibility with business donor audience; comfortable fundraising ask; community connector; can co-MC with client for balanced perspective.

---

### **Sponsorship Hooks**

**Naming Tiers:**
- **Presenting Sponsor** ($5,000): Logo on all materials, truck signage, speaking opportunity, 10 tickets, social media recognition, "named route" for year
- **Impact Sponsor** ($2,500): Logo on event materials, program ad, 6 tickets, social media shout-out, seed packet or meal sponsorship
- **Community Champion** ($1,000): Listing on signage, program ad, 4 tickets, website recognition
- **Friend of the Hollers** ($500): Program listing, 2 tickets

**Sponsored Segments:**
- **Welcome Reception Sponsor** ($1,500): Signage at entry, beverage branding, brief welcome remarks
- **Mobile Pantry Tour Sponsor** ($2,000): Branded tour stop, logo on truck display, volunteer vests
- **Storytelling Moment Sponsor** ($1,000): Introduce storyteller, video credit, program acknowledgment
- **Accessibility Sponsor** ($1,500): Fund interpretation, accessible transport, sensory space—strong mission alignment and PR value
- **Music/Entertainment Sponsor** ($1,000): Stage signage, emcee mentions, program credit
- **Seed Packet/Recipe Booklet Sponsor** ($500 each): Logo on take-home items, lasting brand visibility

**Tangible Assets:**
- Stage/tent banners (reusable across events)
- Digital toolkit: social media graphics, email signatures, website slider
- Print program ads (full page $300, half page $150)
- Logo on event swag (seed packets, recipe cards, reusable totes)
- Matching gift challenges (sponsor matches first $5K raised = doubling impact)
- Route naming rights (annual $2,500+ donors)

---

### **Beneficiary/Volunteer Involvement**

**Authentic Program Participant Roles:**
- **Client Storytellers**: Share 5–7 minute story at events (provide coaching, talking points, practice session); compensate with stipend or gift card ($50–75) and meal
- **Client Greeters**: Welcome guests, share brief personal connection to pantry, distribute programs (builds confidence, visibility)
- **Recipe/Gardening Demonstrators**: Teach seed-planting, share family recipes at tastings (honors expertise, cultural knowledge)
- **Advisory Input**: Invite 2–3 clients to review event plans for accessibility, cultural sensitivity, relevance (December planning meeting; provide meal, childcare, stipend)
- **Mobile Pantry Tour Guides**: Ride-along program participants or regular clients co-lead truck tours with staff

**Meaningful Volunteer Roles Beyond Logistics:**
- **Host Committee**: 8–12 community members recruit guests, sell tickets within networks, serve as table captains (peer-to-peer fundraising)
- **Storytelling Coaches**: Retired teachers or communications professionals help clients prepare and practice stories
- **Auction Item Solicitors**: Small business owners recruit in-kind donations from peer businesses (leverages relationships staff don't have)
- **Farm/Garden Ambassadors**: Extension Master Gardeners staff activity stations, answer questions, reinforce mission
- **Social Media Champions**: 5–6 volunteers share event posts, recruit online, livestream support (especially younger supporters, teachers)
- **Accessibility Ambassadors**: Volunteers with lived disability experience review plans, staff low-sensory spaces, provide tours

---

## 6) NEXT STEPS & DECISION TIMELINE

### **Quick-Win Pilots**

1. **Mini Porch Concert** (Late February): Single house concert with 8–10 board members/champions at ED or board chair's home. Musician performs, client shares story, test donation ask. Goal: $500–800 raised; refine host toolkit. Cost: $150 musician stipend + snacks.

2. **Seed Swap Saturday** (Mid-March): Partner with Extension for free 90-minute gathering. Distribute seeds, share 2–3 stories, tour mobile pantry, collect email sign-ups. Goal: Test storytelling, build interest for May garden event, recruit volunteers. Cost: $100 seeds/printing.

---

### **Validation Plan**

Survey/interview 20–30 target audience members (past donors, church contacts, business owners, teachers) with these questions:

1. Which event concept appeals most to you, and why?
2. What ticket price feels accessible for you and your family/colleagues? ($15? $25? $40?)
3. Would you attend an outdoor May event? What would make you comfortable (tent, accessible parking, kids' activities)?
4. Would you consider hosting a small house concert or watch party? Why or why not?
5. How do you prefer to hear about our mission—stories, data, tours, videos?
6. What local businesses or community groups should we partner with?

**Methods:** 10-minute phone calls (15 people); online survey (email to 100+ contacts); focus group at February church potluck (8–10 attendees).

---

### **Decision Timeline**

- **Week 1–2 (Nov 4–15)**: Board and staff review concepts; distribute validation survey; conduct 10 phone interviews
- **Week 3 (Nov 18–22)**: Compile feedback; development coordinator presents top 3 recommendations with pilot results to board committee
- **Week 4 (Nov 25)**: Board approves primary event + optional pilot; authorize budget and timeline
- **Week 5 (Dec 2)**: Kickoff planning; assign roles; begin sponsor prospecting

---

### **90-Day Pre-Approval Tasks (December–February)**

1. **Venue Holds**: Contact Extension, churches, farms for May date holds; confirm accessibility features; negotiate in-kind/reduced rates. *Owner: Volunteer Coordinator, by Dec 15.*

2. **Budget Model**: Build detailed expense and revenue spreadsheet for chosen concept; identify cost-saving opportunities; set net revenue target. *Owner: Development Coordinator, by Dec 20.*

3. **Sponsor Prospecting List + Packages**: Identify 15–20 prospect businesses/individuals; create 1-page sponsorship menu with tiers and benefits; draft ask emails/letters. *Owner: ED + Development Coordinator, by Jan 10.*

4. **Staffing/Volunteer Plan**: Recruit host committee or volunteer leads (auction, setup, etc.); create volunteer job descriptions and timeline; schedule training sessions. *Owner: Volunteer Coordinator, by Jan 20.*

5. **Accessibility Plan**: Confirm venue accessibility audit; arrange Spanish interpretation; design low-sensory space; finalize sliding-scale policy and scholarship process. *Owner: Development Coordinator + accessibility advisor, by Jan 30.*

6. **Risk/Contingency**: Identify top 5 risks (weather, low ticket sales, sponsor shortfall, volunteer gaps, tech failures); create mitigation plan for each; set "go/no-go" decision point (March 15). *Owner: ED, by Feb 1.*

7. **Initial Marketing Timeline**: Draft save-the-date, create event Facebook page, schedule email blasts, pitch to WMMT radio and local papers, design print postcards. *Owner: Development Coordinator, by Feb 10.*

---

*This brainstorm provides a menu of tested, accessible, mission-rich options. Combining a primary event (e.g., Seeds & Stories Garden Party) with a low-lift pilot (Porch Concert or Gratitude Gathering) and a digital component (Lightning Challenge or Virtual Storytelling Night) could diversify risk and maximize your $20K goal while honoring capacity constraints. The community is ready to gather—let's give them a table worth coming to.*

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally strong output that demonstrates deep understanding of nonprofit fundraising, rural community dynamics, and Appalachian culture. The tone is perfectly warm and mission-focused, concepts are creative yet feasible, and the practical implementation details show real-world expertise. Minor weaknesses include some optimistic revenue projections and occasional formulaic phrasing.
strengths: Outstanding cultural competence—concepts authentically reflect Appalachian values (porch parties, seed packets, hollers language, bluegrass) without stereotyping
Exceptional attention to accessibility throughout—every concept addresses wheelchair access, Spanish interpretation, sliding scale, sensory needs, not as afterthought but integrated design
Highly practical implementation details—specific venue suggestions (UK Extension, named churches), realistic cost drivers, concrete mitigation strategies show real nonprofit experience
Creative differentiation—avoids clichés while staying feasible (progressive dinner across hollers, empty bowl supper, route ride-alongs are fresh but doable)
Strong revenue realism—concepts acknowledge the $20K net goal is ambitious on <$5K budget and provide diversification strategy (series, hybrid, peer-to-peer)
Excellent use of constraints—low-cost concepts clearly identified, capacity intensity ratings honest, weather-resilient options prioritized per risk tolerance
Actionable validation plan—specific survey questions, realistic timeline, quick-win pilots that actually test assumptions cheaply
Authentic voice—'hollers,' 'neighbor-helping-neighbor,' regional references feel genuine not performative; warm tone without being saccharine
weaknesses: Some revenue projections may be optimistic—$20K net from porch concert series assumes very high per-event yield ($1,500-2,250 net × 6-8 events) which requires exceptional execution in a rural, modest-income community
A few concepts stretch the <$5K budget constraint—Mobile Market Auction and Progressive Dinner likely exceed budget even with in-kind support, though this is acknowledged in cost drivers
Occasional formulaic AI phrasing—'tangible connection,' 'leverages existing,' 'honors regional heritage' appear repeatedly; a human editor would vary language more
Comparison matrix scoring could be more differentiated—five concepts tie at 22, suggesting scoring may be slightly generous or insufficiently granular to distinguish trade-offs

outputs.content:
Prepared by Devin Patel, Director of Development for Executive Director + Board Development Committee on November 2, 2025

### 1) EXECUTIVE SNAPSHOT

Windy City Code Bridge (WCCB) is looking to host a high-impact event in Late Summer 2025 to advance economic mobility for immigrants and refugees in Chicago through tech training and job placement. Our primary goal is to **engage 50 new major donor prospects and raise visibility with tech employers**, aiming for **$40,000 net after expenses** from **200–250 in-person attendees and 100 virtual particpants**, supported by **$60,000 from 5–7 sponsors**. Key constraints include an all-in budget of **$25,000–35,000**, with a lean team of dedicated staff and a volunteer host committee. We’ll focus on accessible venues in Chicago’s urban core, River North, or Fulton Market. The event will be hybrid, featuring alumni stories, employer roundtables, and apprenticeship showcases. We need to differentiate from summer tech meetups and galas, offering a creative format, while prioritizing ADA compliance, inclusive pricing, and diverse dietary options. This event is crucial for securing funds and connections to expand our vital programs.

### 2) EVENT CONCEPT PORTFOLIO

**1. Code & Connect: Tech for Good Mixer**
- Tagline/Theme: Bridging talent and opportunity through Chicago's tech community.
- Mission Connection: Directly connects WCCB graduates with tech employers and civic leaders, facilitating job placement and donor engagement.
- Audience Fit: Appeals to tech professionals looking for networking with a social impact angle, and HR leaders seeking diverse talent.
- Experience: A lively, interactive networking reception with stations for quick "speed-interview" style intros, digital portfolio displays from WCCB alumni, and a brief, impactful program featuring a success story and a quick employer panel.
- Venue/Season: Modern co-working space or event loft in Fulton Market/River North; early evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Ground-floor or elevator accessibility, CART/ASL for program, quiet zone available, gender-neutral restrooms, varied food stations including halal/vegetarian, sliding-scale tickets, free student passes.
- Differentiation Hook: More curated and mission-driven than a typical tech mixer; focuses on direct talent connection rather than just general networking.
- Revenue Model: Ticket price $75–100, "Sponsor a Scholar" ticket option, corporate table sponsorships, branded networking zones.
- Cost Drivers: Venue rental, catering, AV/tech support for hybrid.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires strong event management for flow and sponsor integration.

**2. Innovate & Integrate: Chicago Tech Solutions Showcase**
- Tagline/Theme: Real-world problems, diverse talent, innovative solutions.
- Mission Connection: Showcases the practical skills of WCCB graduates through short, impactful project presentations, directly appealing to their future employers.
- Audience Fit: Caters to tech leaders interested in practical, community-driven innovation and talent acquisition, and major donor prospects seeking measurable impact.
- Experience: A "science fair" style evening where WCCB alumni present solutions to local community (or mock-company) challenges through interactive demos and quick pitches. Includes an employer panel discussing hiring best practices.
- Venue/Season: University tech lab or innovation hub (e.g., 1871); Late Summer evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA accessible venue, CART/ASL for panel, quiet rooms, gender-neutral restrooms, inclusive food options, sliding-scale/free passes.
- Differentiation Hook: Hands-on, project-based demonstration of talent, moving beyond resumes to real skill display. Avoids typical pitch night feel by focusing on social good.
- Revenue Model: Ticket price $100–125 (includes light dinner), themed sponsorships for project areas, major donation pledges for program expansion, virtual access passes.
- Cost Drivers: AV setup for demos, catering, venue rental.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires significant coordination with alumni for projects and setup.

**3. The SkillBridge Challenge: Micro-Hackathon for Impact**
- Tagline/Theme: Code for a cause, connect for a career.
- Mission Connection: Puts WCCB graduates and current students in collaborative, skill-demonstrating roles alongside tech professionals, building community connections and tangible solutions.
- Audience Fit: Engages hands-on tech professionals who want to apply their skills for good, and employers seeking to observe talent in action.
- Experience: A focused half-day micro-hackathon where mixed teams (WCCB alumni/students + attending tech pros) tackle a small, defined challenge for a non-profit partner. Concludes with a brief showcase and awards.
- Venue/Season: Corporate training center or tech co-working space; Saturday afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Fully accessible venue, dedicated tech support for all participants, quiet work zones, varied dietary options (halal/vegetarian), gender-neutral restrooms, free registration for WCCB participants.
- Differentiation Hook: Not just a hackathon, but a direct pathway for WCCB talent to collaborate and be assessed by potential employers in a low-pressure, high-impact setting.
- Revenue Model: Team registration fees ($150–200/team), corporate challenge sponsorship, "mentor a team" sponsorship, virtual viewing access to presentations.
- Cost Drivers: Venue (if not donated), tech support, food/drinks for participants, prizes.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires strong logistical planning and partner outreach for challenges.

**4. Journeys to Code: Storytelling & Sponsorship Supper**
- Tagline/Theme: Hear their journey, invest in their future.
- Mission Connection: Centers authentic narratives of immigrant and refugee tech professionals, fostering empathy and direct major donor engagement.
- Audience Fit: Appeals to civic-minded investors and major donor prospects who appreciate intimate storytelling and direct impact.
- Experience: An elegant, seated dinner with a powerful program featuring 2-3 WCCB alumni sharing their personal journeys. Each table hosted by a WCCB board member or prominent supporter to facilitate conversation and pledges.
- Venue/Season: Private dining room at a Chicago restaurant or elegant event space; Late Summer evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA compliant venue, CART/ASL for speakers, printed programs in large font, varied dietary options (halal/vegetarian), gender-neutral restrooms. Intimate setting naturally fosters inclusion.
- Differentiation Hook: High-touch, emotionally resonant event focused on direct impact stories rather than broad industry discussion. Moves beyond traditional gala format with focused storytelling.
- Revenue Model: Table sponsorships ($2,500–5,000), individual tickets ($150–200), direct ask/pledges during program, mission moment sponsorship.
- Cost Drivers: Catering/venue, AV for presentations, decor.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW – smaller guest count, relies on host committee for outreach.

**5. Decoding Diversity: An Employer Roundtable & Networking Brunch**
- Tagline/Theme: Beyond the resume: unlocking Chicago's diverse tech talent.
- Mission Connection: Directly engages HR/talent acquisition leaders in conversations about diverse hiring, positioning WCCB as a key talent pipeline.
- Audience Fit: Highly targeted for HR/talent acquisition leaders and C-suite executives interested in DEI and talent strategy. Attracts donors interested in policy and systemic impact.
- Experience: A structured morning with moderated roundtable discussions on topics like "Building Inclusive Tech Teams" or "Leveraging Non-Traditional Pathways," followed by an informal networking brunch with WCCB leadership and select alumni.
- Venue/Season: Corporate event space or high-end hotel conference room; weekday morning/early afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Accessible venue, CART/ASL for all panels, quiet zones, diverse food options, gender-neutral restrooms, sponsored tickets for small businesses/non-profits.
- Differentiation Hook: Positions WCCB as an industry thought leader on diverse talent acquisition, offering practical insights rather than just a recruitment fair.
- Revenue Model: Corporate sponsorships (table hosts, topic sponsors), individual tickets $100–150, premium virtual access pass (includes white paper), "Breakfast with an Expert" add-on.
- Cost Drivers: Venue rental, catering, speaker fees (if outside expert), marketing.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires strong outreach to corporate decision-makers and expert moderators.

**6. The Tech Navigator Race: Urban Exploration & Career Quest (Low-Cost / Scalable Pilot)**
- Tagline/Theme: Charting a course to opportunity, one step at a time.
- Mission Connection: Highlights the journey and resilience of WCCB participants and connects them to key tech landmarks and employers in Chicago.
- Audience Fit: Appeals to younger tech professionals and teams looking for an active, engaging, community-building event; also families.
- Experience: A city-wide scavenger hunt/race using a mobile app, guiding teams to various tech and civic landmarks, with WCCB alumni or employer representatives at certain checkpoints to share mini-stories or challenges. Concludes at a central, accessible location for a celebration.
- Venue/Season: Urban core/Fulton Market/River North districts; Saturday afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Fully accessible checkpoints, clear printed instructions/map, varied pace groups, accessible meeting point for non-participating supporters, free student team entry.
- Differentiation Hook: Combines physical activity, local exploration, and direct mission engagement in a fun, team-based format, distinct from a typical run/walk.
- Revenue Model: Team registration fees ($50–100/team), checkpoint sponsorships, corporate team challenges, t-shirt sales.
- Cost Drivers: App development/licensing, prizes, marketing materials, insurance.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW – scalable, can start small and expand locations.

**7. "Hire & Inspire" Virtual Career Fair + Panel (Hybrid / Low-Cost)**
- Tagline/Theme: Connecting Chicago's tech talent with leading employers, wherever you are.
- Mission Connection: Provides a direct digital bridge between WCCB graduates and tech employers, overcoming geographical barriers.
- Audience Fit: Broad appeal for busy HR/talent acquisition leaders, WCCB alumni, and individuals seeking flexible engagement.
- Experience: A dedicated virtual platform featuring employer booths (with company videos, job openings, and live chat), a main stage for a panel discussion on inclusive hiring, and breakout rooms for specific employer info sessions. In-person component is a viewing party + networking.
- Venue/Season: Hybrid: Virtual platform + small in-person hub (e.g., WCCB office or donated space); weekday afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Fully accessible virtual platform, live captions/ASL on main stage, text alternatives, quiet zones at in-person hub, virtual chat moderators for support.
- Differentiation Hook: High-quality hybrid experience focused on direct connections and practical career insights, not just a static job board.
- Revenue Model: Employer booth fees ($500–1,500), premium employer sponsorships (featured speaker, dedicated outreach), standard attendee registration (free–$25), virtual 'swag bag' sponsorships.
- Cost Drivers: Virtual platform subscription, marketing, AV for live components.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires strong tech and marketing coordination.

**8. The Immigrant Innovations Gala (Reimagined)**
- Tagline/Theme: Celebrating the ingenuity and impact of new Chicagoans in tech.
- Mission Connection: Elevates the profile of immigrant tech talent and positions WCCB as a critical engine for innovation and economic growth.
- Audience Fit: Attracts civic-minded investors, major donors, and senior tech leaders who appreciate a formal celebration of impact.
- Experience: A refined evening event, but with a strong emphasis on interactive tech showcases by WCCB alumni and "micro-talks" on immigrant contributions to tech preceding the main program. Features a keynote by a prominent immigrant tech entrepreneur.
- Venue/Season: Elevated event space in River North; Late Summer evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA venue, CART/ASL for program, quiet lounge area, gender-neutral restrooms, gourmet halal/vegetarian options, sponsored tickets for alumni.
- Differentiation Hook: Reimagines the traditional "gala" as an interactive celebration of innovation and resilience, with an underlying theme of empowering WCCB "alumni as innovators," distinct from typical tech industry awards.
- Revenue Model: Premier table sponsorships ($5,000–10,000), individual tickets ($200–350), live appeal/paddle raise, innovation showcase sponsorships.
- Cost Drivers: Catering, venue, AV production, speaker fees.
- Capacity Intensity: HIGH – more complex logistics, higher expectations for production.

**9. Tech Trek: Chicago's Innovation Walkabout**
- Tagline/Theme: Discovering Chicago's tech ecosystem, empowering new talent.
- Mission Connection: Physically grounds WCCB's mission within the Chicago tech landscape, showcasing opportunities and connecting participants to potential employers' physical spaces (or facades).
- Audience Fit: Appeals to curious tech professionals, community supporters, and individuals seeking a unique way to experience the city and its tech scene.
- Experience: Guided walking tours of tech hubs in Fulton Market/River North, possibly including short informal visits to co-working spaces or company lobbies (if feasible). Alumni share stories at key locations; concludes with a casual reception.
- Venue/Season: Specific neighborhoods in Chicago; Saturday morning.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Wheelchair accessible routes, ASL interpreters for guides (upon request), frequent rest stops, options for shorter routes, free admission for WCCB community.
- Differentiation Hook: Combines the growing popularity of themed city tours with a direct mission focus and networking opportunity. Low-cost and highly engaging.
- Revenue Model: Ticket sales ($50–75), corporate tour sponsorships (e.g., "Google Stop Sponsor"), "guide a group" peer-to-peer fundraising, reception sponsorship.
- Cost Drivers: Guide fees, permits (if needed), marketing, reception.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW – easily scaled by adding more routes/guides.

**10. Mentors & Mavericks: Speed Mentoring & Networking (Low-Cost / Scalable Pilot)**
- Tagline/Theme: Guiding the next generation of tech leaders.
- Mission Connection: Provides invaluable professional development and networking opportunities for WCCB students and alumni, while engaging tech leaders as mentors and potential donors.
- Audience Fit: Appeals to established tech professionals eager to give back and rising stars seeking guidance; a prime major donor cultivation opportunity.
- Experience: A structured speed-mentoring session where WCCB alumni/students rotate through tables with tech mentors, followed by open networking with light refreshments.
- Venue/Season: Donated corporate boardroom or large co-working space; weekday evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: Accessible venue, clear instructions, designated quiet areas, diverse mentor pool, gender-neutral restrooms, inclusive food options, free for WCCB participants.
- Differentiation Hook: Focuses purely on professional development and relationship building, making it a valuable use of time for busy tech leaders, rather than a fundraising ask in itself.
- Revenue Model: "Sponsor a Mentor Table" ($500–1,000), individual tickets ($75–100), corporate matching for mentor's time, virtual follow-up mentorship platform sponsorship.
- Cost Drivers: Venue (if paid), light catering, marketing materials, mentor recruitment.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW – scalable small (20-30 people) to medium (50-70).

**11. The Code Canvas: Digital Art & Tech Talent Exhibit**
- Tagline/Theme: Where creativity meets code in Chicago.
- Mission Connection: Showcases the creative and technical application of coding skills, broadening the perception of tech talent and WCCB's curriculum.
- Audience Fit: Attracts artists, creative tech professionals, and companies looking for design/UX talent, and those interested in cross-disciplinary innovation.
- Experience: An interactive exhibition featuring digital art, web design projects, or even small interactive installations created by WCCB alumni. Includes a live demo booth and a "meet the artist/developer" session.
- Venue/Season: Art gallery, large open-plan office, or flexible event space; evening reception.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA venue, clear exhibition labels, interactive elements for diverse abilities, quiet viewing times, gender-neutral restrooms, diverse food options.
- Differentiation Hook: Blends art and tech, offering a unique and visually engaging way to showcase WCCB talent, differentiating from purely technical showcases.
- Revenue Model: Ticket sales ($75–100), art sales (commission to WCCB), exhibition sponsorships (e.g., "Interactive Experience Sponsor"), virtual gallery access.
- Cost Drivers: Venue (if not donated), AV rental, marketing, refreshments.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM – requires coordination with alumni for creative output.

**12. Passport to Tech: Global Flavor & Local Talent Festival (Hybrid)**
- Tagline/Theme: Experience the world's tech talent, right here in Chicago.
- Mission Connection: Celebrates the diverse cultural backgrounds of WCCB participants, tying their unique perspectives to their tech skills and fostering a sense of community.
- Audience Fit: Appeals to a broader audience interested in cultural experiences, food, and community, alongside tech professionals and employers.
- Experience: A lively festival environment featuring cultural performances, food stations representing different immigrant cuisines, and interactive "global tech village" booths where WCCB alumni from various backgrounds showcase projects or discuss their unique journey into tech. Includes a virtual "global tour" option.
- Venue/Season: Large indoor market space (e.g., Chicago French Market area if available, or similar concept) or multi-purpose event hall; weekend afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA accessible, quiet zones, diverse food vendors (halal/vegetarian options from specific cultures), ASL/CART for main stage performances, gender-neutral restrooms.
- Differentiation Hook: Combines cultural celebration with tech showcase and career fair elements, making it a truly unique and vibrant event. Far from a typical tech meetup or gala.
- Revenue Model: Individual tickets ($50–75), food vendor fees, "Culture Booth" sponsorships, employer recruitment booths, virtual access.
- Cost Drivers: Venue, food vendors, entertainment, marketing, security.
- Capacity Intensity: HIGH – requires extensive coordination with vendors and performers.

### 3) COMPARISON MATRIX

| Concept # and Title                            | Mission Alignment | Net Revenue Potential | Audience Appeal | Differentiation | Feasibility/Capacity | TOTAL SCORE |
|:-----------------------------------------------|:------------------|:----------------------|:----------------|:----------------|:---------------------|:------------|
| 1. Code & Connect: Tech for Good Mixer         | 5                 | 4                     | 4               | 4               | 4                    | 21          |
| 2. Innovate & Integrate: Chicago Tech Solutions Showcase | 5                 | 4                     | 4               | 5               | 3                    | 21          |
| 3. The SkillBridge Challenge: Micro-Hackathon  | 5                 | 3                     | 4               | 5               | 3                    | 20          |
| 4. Journeys to Code: Storytelling & Sponsorship Supper | 5                 | 5                     | 3               | 4               | 4                    | 21          |
| 5. Decoding Diversity: Employer Roundtable     | 4                 | 4                     | 5               | 4               | 3                    | 20          |
| 6. The Tech Navigator Race                     | 4                 | 3                     | 4               | 5               | 5                    | 21          |
| 7. "Hire & Inspire" Virtual Career Fair        | 5                 | 3                     | 4               | 4               | 4                    | 20          |
| 8. The Immigrant Innovations Gala (Reimagined) | 5                 | 5                     | 3               | 3               | 2                    | 18          |
| 9. Tech Trek: Chicago's Innovation Walkabout   | 4                 | 3                     | 4               | 4               | 5                    | 20          |
| 10. Mentors & Mavericks: Speed Mentoring      | 5                 | 3                     | 4               | 4               | 5                    | 21          |
| 11. The Code Canvas: Digital Art & Exhibit    | 4                 | 3                     | 3               | 5               | 3                    | 18          |
| 12. Passport to Tech: Global Flavor & Talent  | 5                 | 4                     | 5               | 5               | 2                    | 21          |

Key: 5 = Excellent; 4 = Good; 3 = Adequate; 2 = Weak; 1 = Poor.

### 4) TOP 3 RECOMMENDATIONS

**1. Journeys to Code: Storytelling & Sponsorship Supper**
- Why This Concept: This concept is highly effective for engaging new major donor prospects due to its intimate, mission-driven storytelling format. It offers a direct, emotional connection to WCCB's impact, which is crucial for high-net-worth individuals. The focused format minimizes logistical complexity, fitting our team's capacity while maximizing net revenue potential through high-value table sponsorships and pledges.
- Key Risks: Relying on a smaller, higher-ticket attendance means fewer overall attendees; potential for the event to feel exclusive rather than inclusive for some audiences; securing compelling alumni speakers.
- Mitigations: Offer a virtual "story stream" or post-event video; ensure diverse representation on host committee and invite list; work closely with alumni for storytelling coaching; proactively identify and train host committee members to make all guests feel welcome.
- Quick Win Potential: Host a small, similar dinner with current board members and top donors to test the format and gather feedback on storytelling effectiveness before a larger launch.

**2. Code & Connect: Tech for Good Mixer**
- Why This Concept: This concept brilliantly balances revenue generation, employer visibility, and donor engagement through direct networking. Its interactive, modern format appeals strongly to our target audience of tech professionals and HR leaders, differentiating it from traditional events. The hybrid component broadens reach, and its structure allows for multiple sponsorship opportunities.
- Key Risks: Ensuring genuine connections rather than superficial networking; managing attendee flow in a hybrid environment; initial tech setup for digital portfolio displays.
- Mitigations: Provide icebreakers and structured intros; dedicated virtual hosts to moderate chats and facilitate connections; have technical support on-site; provide clear instructions for alumni portfolio creation.
- Quick Win Potential: Organize a smaller "speed networking" session with a few key employers and WCCB alumni to refine the format and gather testimonials.

**3. The Tech Navigator Race: Urban Exploration & Career Quest**
- Why This Concept: This concept offers exceptional creative differentiation and scalability while engaging a younger, active tech professional audience. It's a low-cost, high-engagement way to raise visibility and attract new philanthropic interest from a demographic interested in experiential giving. Its community-oriented nature strengthens WCCB’s local ties.
- Key Risks: Weather dependency for an outdoor event; ensuring accessibility for all checkpoints; potential for logistic complexity with multiple race points.
- Mitigations: Have a rain date or accessible indoor alternative; pre-scout all routes for ADA compliance and provide clear, varied difficulty routes; utilize a strong volunteer corps and mobile app for real-time coordination.
- Quick Win Potential: Pilot a smaller "mini-race" within a single tech campus or neighborhood with WCCB staff, alumni, and host committee as participants to test the concept and app functionality.

### 5) IMPLEMENTATION SUPPORT

**Potential Partners/Hosts:**
*   **Venues:** 1871 (tech hub), tech-forward hotel conference spaces in River North (e.g., The Godfrey, Holiday Inn Mart Plaza), Fulton Market event lofts (e.g., Morgan Manufacturing, City Winery), City Colleges of Chicago facilities (for specific programming/classrooms).
*   **Community Orgs:** ICIRR (immigrant/refugee support), local dev meetup groups (ChicagoJS, PyLadies Chicago), ChiTech Academy (youth development aligns with talent pipeline story).
*   **Media Partners:** Built In Chicago, Crain's Chicago Business (tech section), local tech blogs/podcasts, Block Club Chicago (community engagement stories).
*   **In-Kind Sources:** Tech companies for venue donation, AV equipment, food/beverage donations for informal components, printing services.

**Talent/MC Ideas:**
*   **Brendan Reilly:** Alderman, experienced public speaker, tech-friendly.
*   **Maria Contreras-Sweet:** Former White House SBA Administrator, advocate for entrepreneurship/immigrant communities. (Note: May require significant lead time/fee).
*   **Local Tech Founders/CEOs:** Look for leaders of successful Chicago tech startups known for their inclusive hiring practices (e.g., leaders from Built In, Grubhub, Morningstar).
*   **WCCB Alumni Success Stories:** Authenticity in storytelling is key. Feature graduates who have secured impactful roles.
*   **Chicago-based Tech Journalists/Influencers:** Someone like a tech editor from Chicago Inno or a prominent tech podcaster who knows the local scene.

**Sponsorship Hooks:**
*   **Presenting Sponsor:** Top billing on all materials, keynote introduction, exclusive branding opportunity.
*   **Innovation Catalyst Sponsor:** Funds a specific showcase or challenge.
*   **Opportunity Bridge Sponsor:** Underwrites tickets for WCCB students/alumni and accessibility features.
*   **Talent Pipeline Partner:** Featured employer booth/spotlight, speaking slot on employer panel.
*   **Networking Hub Sponsor:** Branding for a specific networking area/virtual room.
*   **Custom "Mission Moment" Sponsorship:** Sponsor the storytelling segment or an alumni success video.

**Beneficiary/Volunteer Involvement:**
*   **Authentic Roles for Program Participants:**
    *   **Speakers/Panelists:** Alumni sharing personal journeys and professional success.
    *   **Project Presenters/Demonstrators:** Current students and alumni showcasing their technical projects.
    *   **Ambassadors/Hosts:** Greeting attendees, guiding tours, answering questions about WCCB.
    *   **Content Creators:** Assisting with video testimonials, social media takeovers, blog posts.
*   **Meaningful Volunteer Roles Beyond Logistics:**
    *   **Host Committee:** Lead ticket sales, corporate outreach, and donor engagement.
    *   **Mentor Network:** Tech professionals providing pre-event resume reviews and day-of speed mentoring.
    *   **Accessibility Liaisons:** Ensuring all attendees have needs met, assisting with ASL/CART coordination.
    *   **Event Day Leads:** Overseeing specific areas (e.g., registration, Q&A moderator, tech support) to lighten staff load.

### 6) NEXT STEPS & DECISION TIMELINE

**Quick-Win Pilots:**
*   **"Micro-Mentoring Mixer":** A short, focused speed mentoring session in a donated corporate office for 15-20 WCCB alumni/students and 5-7 tech mentors. Capture stories and feedback.
*   **"Alumni Story Spotlight":** Record 2-3 high-quality video testimonials from WCCB alumni to use in early fundraising asks and promotional materials, establishing a strong mission-forward narrative.

**Validation Plan:**
*   **Survey Current Donors/Employers** (online, quick poll): "What kind of event would compel you to attend/sponsor?" "What's the best use of your time/investment?"
*   **Brief Calls with Host Committee Candidates:** Discuss preferred event formats, potential connections, and time commitment.
*   **Focus Group with Tech Professionals (25-45):** "What makes an event in Chicago's tech scene stand out?" "What's your motivation for attending mission-driven events?"
*   **Employer Needs Assessment:** Informal conversations with 5-10 HR/talent acquisition leaders: "What are your biggest hiring challenges?" "How can WCCB better connect you with talent?"
*   **Competitive Event Audit:** Analyze marketing, attendance, and feedback from similar summer tech events.

**Decision Timeline:**
*   **Week 1–2 (Early November):** Gather stakeholder input via surveys and initial calls. Present full portfolio of concepts to Executive Director + Board Development Committee.
*   **Week 3 (Mid-November):** Decision on top 1-2 event concepts for development. Start identifying key venue targets.
*   **Week 4 (Late November):** Announce chosen concept(s). Kick-off initial planning meetings.

**90-Day Pre-Approval Tasks (Late Nov – Feb):**
*   **Venue Holds:** Secure preliminary holds for 2-3 preferred venues.
*   **Budget Model:** Develop detailed financial projections for chosen concept(s), including expense breakdowns and revenue targets.
*   **Sponsor Prospecting List + Packages:** Create a tiered sponsorship deck and identify a target list of 20-30 potential corporate sponsors.
*   **Staffing/Volunteer Plan:** Outline detailed roles and responsibilities for staff and a recruited host committee.
*   **Accessibility Plan:** Develop a comprehensive accessibility checklist for the chosen venue and format, including vendor requirements (ASL, CART, halal food).
*   **Risk/Contingency Plan:** Identify key potential risks (e.g., low attendance, tech failures, weather) and outline mitigation strategies.
*   **Initial Marketing Timeline:** Draft a high-level marketing and communications plan for the event launch.

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly professional, comprehensive event planning document that demonstrates strong understanding of nonprofit fundraising and the Chicago tech ecosystem. It successfully balances creative differentiation with practical constraints, offering genuinely distinct concepts rather than generic templates. Minor weaknesses include some ambitious assumptions about sponsorship revenue relative to budget and a few concepts that may require more capacity than indicated.
strengths: Exceptional concept diversity with genuine creative differentiation - concepts like 'Tech Navigator Race,' 'Code Canvas,' and 'Passport to Tech' avoid clichés and offer fresh approaches that align authentically with the mission

Thorough accessibility integration throughout every concept, not as an afterthought but as a core design element (CART/ASL, halal/vegetarian, sliding scale, gender-neutral restrooms consistently addressed)
Strong mission alignment with concrete connections - each concept explicitly ties back to immigrant/refugee tech talent pipeline rather than generic fundraising language
Practical, actionable implementation support including specific Chicago venues (1871, Fulton Market), realistic local partners (ICIRR, ChiTech Academy), and concrete pilot ideas
Excellent use of casual tone as requested - approachable, energizing language without sacrificing professionalism ('Mavericks,' 'Walkabout,' conversational headers)
Realistic capacity assessments with honest HIGH ratings for complex events like the gala and festival, helping decision-makers understand true resource requirements
Strong comparison matrix that provides genuine differentiation in scoring rather than inflating all concepts equally
Comprehensive validation plan with specific, useful questions rather than generic 'survey stakeholders' advice
weaknesses: Sponsorship goal of $60K against a $25-35K budget is ambitious but not explicitly addressed as a constraint or risk - the concepts don't clearly show how to achieve nearly 2:1 sponsorship-to-expense ratio

Some capacity intensity ratings may be optimistic - 'Tech Navigator Race' rated LOW but requires app development, insurance, multiple checkpoint coordination, and significant volunteer management which typically demands MEDIUM capacity

The 'Immigrant Innovations Gala (Reimagined)' concept, while attempting differentiation, still carries high production costs and complexity that may not sufficiently distinguish it from the 'avoid gala look/feel' constraint
Minor inconsistency: Executive Snapshot mentions 'particpants' (typo) and the document occasionally uses jargon like 'HHI' without defining it, though context makes it clear

outputs.content:
1) EXECUTIVE SNAPSHOT
Primary Goal: Engage 50 new major donor prospects and raise visibility with tech employers.
Target Audience: Chicago tech professionals and managers ages 25–45 (HHI $90K+), HR/talent leaders at mid-to-large tech firms, and civic-minded investors.
Success Metrics: Net $40,000 after expenses; Attendance 200–250 in person + 100 virtual; Sponsorships $60,000 from 5–7 sponsors (tech, staffing, cloud).
Key Constraints: Late Summer 2025 (Aug/Sept), Chicago (urban core/River North/Fulton Market), $25,000–35,000 all-in; staff time limited; medium risk tolerance; must be ADA accessible with CART/ASL, gender-neutral restrooms, halal/veg options, sliding-scale tickets + free student passes; hybrid-capable stream + moderated chat.
Mission Context: New funds and employer connections expand tech training cohorts and job placements for immigrants and refugees.
Competitive Note: Summer meetups/hackathons abound; big galas in May—so we’ll avoid gala aesthetics and hit late summer.
Must-Include: Alumni job stories, employer roundtable, and apprenticeship partner showcase.
Assumptions: 1871 or sponsor provides in-kind/discounted venue; AV partner supports hybrid; sponsor appetite comparable to 2024.

2) EVENT CONCEPT PORTFOLIO

1. BridgeWorks: Rooftop Tech + Talent Night
- Tagline/Theme: Where Chicago’s tech leaders meet the city’s newest builders—over skyline views.
- Mission Connection: Alumni showcase real job skills; employer chats map to live openings; donations fund cohort seats.
- Audience Fit: Social, high-energy night for tech managers and HR; easy invite for donors and partner execs.
- Experience: Sunset rooftop reception, 6–8 “byte-sized” demos, a 20-minute mission moment, and employer roundtable breakout.
- Venue/Season: Fulton Market or River North rooftop/loft with terrace (e.g., Morgan’s on Fulton, Venue West) in late Aug/Sept.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA elevator routes, CART/ASL for program, gender-neutral restrooms, quiet room, halal/veg buffets; sliding-scale + student passes.
- Differentiation Hook: Not a gala—festival vibe with live code stations and immigrant-owned food vendors.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $95–125; sponsor-branded demo pods, terrace lounge, bar; short “fund a career” pledge drive; employer packages.
- Cost Drivers: Rooftop rental/AV, food & beverage, production.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM—one venue, streamlined run-of-show.

2. Code Bridge Demo Crawl
- Tagline/Theme: A progressive night across 3–4 spaces—each stop unlocks a career story.
- Mission Connection: Demos highlight training-to-job pathways; each stop paired with an apprenticeship partner.
- Audience Fit: Tech pros who love discovery; investors scouting inclusive talent; great for host committee invites.
- Experience: Guided walking crawl with 20-minute sets per location; finale toast with speed intros between alumni and recruiters.
- Venue/Season: Short-walk cluster in River North/Fulton Market (coworking floors, sponsor offices) early evening in Sept.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: All stops ADA; clear route maps; CART/ASL at demo stops; halal/veg tastings; sliding-scale.
- Differentiation Hook: Social + educational journey instead of seated program; immigrant-owned bites at each stop.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $85–115; stop sponsorships; passport stamp raffle; pledge wall for apprenticeship seats.
- Cost Drivers: Security/wayfinding, AV at multiple sites, small bites.
- Capacity Intensity: HIGH—multi-site coordination; scalable to 2–3 stops if needed.

3. Hiring Sprints & Skills Showcase
- Tagline/Theme: 90 minutes. 12 tables. 100+ curated matches. Real jobs.
- Mission Connection: Converts training to interviews; employer commitments tracked; alumni placed.
- Audience Fit: HR/talent leaders seeking vetted candidates; managers needing quick pipeline; donors see direct impact.
- Experience: 10-minute “sprints” between employers and candidates; live skills stations; real-time matching board; debrief mixer.
- Venue/Season: Accessible innovation venue (1871, TechNexus, mHUB) with open floor; late summer weekday afternoon/evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA layout, clear signage, quiet room, CART/ASL for plenary; halal/veg dinner boxes; free alumni/student passes.
- Differentiation Hook: Tight, data-driven matching vs. meandering job fairs; commitments captured live.
- Revenue Model: Employer packages ($1,000–$5,000), tickets for general attendance $75–95; sponsorship of matching board, skills stations, livestream.
- Cost Drivers: AV/stream, data/matching platform support, catering.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM—heavy pre-matching; in-room flow is simple.

4. Routes to Roots: Lightning Talks + Live Podcast (Hybrid, Low-Cost)
- Tagline/Theme: Seven 7-minute talks from immigrant builders—and a live podcast taping.
- Mission Connection: Alumni and mentors share job journeys; donations fund new cohorts.
- Audience Fit: Tech pros love fast, polished talks; pod fans + donors enjoy storytelling.
- Experience: 60-minute lightning talks, 30-minute podcast interview, brief pledge moment; high-quality live stream with chat.
- Venue/Season: 1871 Auditorium or sponsor theater in River North; late Aug weekday evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: CART/ASL for full program, ADA seating, gender-neutral restrooms, sliding-scale + free student passes.
- Differentiation Hook: Media-forward, snackable content; post-event podcast episodes extend reach.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $75–95; podcast Presenting Sponsor; “Captioning/Accessibility Sponsor”; branded episode credits.
- Cost Drivers: AV/stream, staging/lighting, light reception.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW—one set, tight run-of-show.

5. Immigrant Innovators Pitch + Apprenticeship Marketplace
- Tagline/Theme: Pitch for placements—employers commit seats on the spot.
- Mission Connection: Alumni teams pitch real skills; employers pledge apprenticeship/internship slots and interview days.
- Audience Fit: HR leaders and tech managers needing entry talent; donors get a compelling, accountable impact moment.
- Experience: 5–6 short pitches, employer judge Q&A, marketplace with apprenticeship partners; live “commitment counter.”
- Venue/Season: River North stage + adjacent hall (e.g., Convene, The Mart, or sponsor auditorium) in Sept.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA everything; CART/ASL for program; halal/veg service; sliding-scale; translated materials if needed.
- Differentiation Hook: Instead of cash prizes, outcomes are seats and hiring days—publicly pledged.
- Revenue Model: Employer pledge packages ($2,500–$10,000 with branding), tickets $95–125; “Commitment Counter” sponsor; pledge-matching donor.
- Cost Drivers: Venue/AV, staging/producer, reception.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM—program-heavy but single-room.

6. Neighborhood Data Walk + Story Stations (Low-Cost, Scalable)
- Tagline/Theme: Walk the metrics—meet the people behind them.
- Mission Connection: Data on economic mobility layered with alumni stories at street-level stops.
- Audience Fit: Civic-minded tech folks; impact investors; teams seeking a purposeful outing.
- Experience: 1.5-hour guided loop with QR code microsites, short live stories, and an outdoor finale with refreshments.
- Venue/Season: River North/Loop sidewalks + plaza; late summer evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA route; portable seating; CART/ASL at story stops; halal/veg snacks; free student passes.
- Differentiation Hook: Urban storytelling meets data viz; minimal production; great content asset capture.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $75–85; station sponsors; peer-to-peer team fundraising; branded map.
- Cost Drivers: Permits/security, portable sound/CART, capture/photography.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW—lean production.

7. Code Bridge Civic Micro-Hack (Hybrid)
- Tagline/Theme: 3-hour build sprint on tools that speed fair hiring.
- Mission Connection: Teams prototype resume-screen equity checks, referral bots, or language-friendly onboarding flows.
- Audience Fit: Builders who like hands-on; HR teams wanting practical tools; mentors.
- Experience: Opening brief, 100-minute sprint, rapid demos, awards; stream judges’ feedback + highlights.
- Venue/Season: mHUB/1871/open-plan sponsor office; Saturday morning/afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA layout, accessible power/spacing, CART/ASL for program; halal/veg lunch; sliding-scale.
- Differentiation Hook: Short, focused sprint with product owners (alumni/employers) and immediate use cases.
- Revenue Model: Team entries $250–500, tickets $75; sponsor: Dev Tools Stage, Cloud Credits, Accessibility Award.
- Cost Drivers: AV/stream, food, awards.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM—short but coordination-heavy.

8. Employer Roundtable & Talent Matching Salon (Low-Cost, Scalable)
- Tagline/Theme: Off-the-record insights + curated introductions.
- Mission Connection: Aligns curriculum to hiring needs; locks in upcoming interview days.
- Audience Fit: HR, TA directors, and hiring managers who prefer candid, intimate settings.
- Experience: 45-minute Chatham House rules roundtable, 45-minute curated matches, 30-minute mixer.
- Venue/Season: Sponsor boardroom or lounge in Fulton Market; weekday morning or late afternoon.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA access; CART for roundtable; pronoun/visual lanyard options; halal/veg light fare; free alumni.
- Differentiation Hook: Small, senior, outcomes-focused; follow-up commitments tracked publicly.
- Revenue Model: Underwritten by 1–2 sponsors; optional employer seat fee; no/low public ticketing.
- Cost Drivers: Minimal—catering, facilitation, note-taking.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW—white-glove invite list.

9. BridgeFest: Food, Beats, and Byte-sized Demos
- Tagline/Theme: Chicago night market meets tech talent fair.
- Mission Connection: Alumni demo pods; partner apprenticeships as “market stalls”; donations fuel placements.
- Audience Fit: Broad draw—tech teams, donors, investors; fun team outing.
- Experience: DJ + cultural performances, tasting stations from immigrant chefs, demo pods, short mainstage program.
- Venue/Season: Warehouse/loft (Morgan MFG, The Geraghty lite footprint) in Sept.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA flow; CART/ASL for program; quiet room; prayer space; halal/veg abundant; sliding-scale.
- Differentiation Hook: Market vibe, not gala; culinary storytelling tied to career journeys.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $95–125; booth sponsors; “Chef + Tech” stage; branded tasting passports; pledge drive.
- Cost Drivers: Venue/AV, food vendors, entertainment/production.
- Capacity Intensity: HIGH—many moving parts.

10. Virtual Studio: Alumni Job Stories Live (Virtual, Low-Cost)
- Tagline/Theme: One hour, four stories, one clear ask—streamed nationwide.
- Mission Connection: Spotlights training-to-job outcomes; CTA funds new cohorts.
- Audience Fit: Busy execs and remote employers; good for pipeline warming.
- Experience: High-quality multi-cam stream, moderated Q&A/chat, instant-donate overlays; ASL picture-in-picture.
- Venue/Season: Small studio at 1871 or sponsor media room; flexible timing.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: CART + ASL, transcripts, screen-reader friendly landing page; free access.
- Differentiation Hook: Tight storytelling and TV-quality production vs. webinar fatigue.
- Revenue Model: Free stream; sponsor lower-thirds and interstitials; donate buttons; match challenge.
- Cost Drivers: Studio/crew, captioning/ASL, platform.
- Capacity Intensity: LOW—lean team, strong content.

11. Progressive Pop-up Tour: From Arrival to Impact
- Tagline/Theme: A guided arc through coworking labs, immigrant-owned shops, and a rooftop finale.
- Mission Connection: Each stop maps a step in the training-to-placement journey with alumni narrators.
- Audience Fit: Investors and donors who value context; tech teams seeking meaningful exposure.
- Experience: Small-group tours with audio guides, tactile demos, final toast and pledge.
- Venue/Season: River North/Fulton Market cluster; late summer weekend late afternoon–evening.
- Accessibility/Inclusion: ADA route/plans communicated ahead; CART/ASL at content stops; halal/veg; sliding-scale.
- Differentiation Hook: Immersive “museum” of economic mobility across real venues.
- Revenue Model: Tickets $95–115; stop sponsors; curated VIP group underwriters; pledge moments at finale.
- Cost Drivers: Coordination, docents/audio tech, small bites at each stop.
- Capacity Intensity: MEDIUM–HIGH—logistics across sites.

12. Bridge Builder Awards Breakfast (Not-a-Gala)
- Tagline/Theme: Coffee, commitments, and celebrations—out the door by 9:30.
- Mission Connection: Honors employer partners and alumni mentors; invites new hiring pledges.
